newsitem.title: UK: Greece expected to set a 1.0 bln mark 10-year bond.
newsitem.headline: Greece expected to set a 1.0 bln mark 10-year bond.

text.p: The mandate for an expected 1.0 billion mark 10-year fixed-rate Eurobond for Greece is soon to be announced, new issues traders said on Monday.
The bidding process is underway and the announcement is due early next week, they said.
But some syndicate officials in Frankfurt said a 10-year maturity would not be easy to achieve.
Some said a launch spread of around 100 basis points over Bunds could be seen, others said 90 b.p. over the April 2006 Bund was also probable.

"The long-term (mark) sector is extremely difficult to achieve. Institutional investors are not buying long-dated paper and I don't think the yield pick-up will be enough to attract them," a syndicate official said.
"A shorter maturity would be more advisable, but I think Greece has already set their mind on a 10-year transaction," he added.
But another syndicate official in Frankfurt said the five-year mark sector was crowded and they would do better to tap the seven or 10-year sectors.
Greece is rated Baa3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB- by Standard & Poor's Corp.
In mid-August, the country privately placed a 120 million mark FRN to yield 55 b.p. over six-month LIBOR.
It launched a 1.0 billion mark seven-year Eurobond off its EMTN Programme in mid-January via joint lead managers WestLB and Salomon Brothers.
The bond yielded 100 b.p. over the 7.125 percent Treuhand due January 2003.
